intro: Acaena sanguisorbae var. pilosa, commonly known as the hairy burr weed, is a perennial plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its prickly, spherical fruits that contain seeds. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forests and along stream banks. Its hairy stems and leaves are adapted to retain moisture in its native habitat. The species is often considered a weed due to its aggressive growth and ability to spread rapidly.
